title: Comprehensive metabolome analysis of intracellular metabolites in cultured cells
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
An overview of the metabolite extraction is shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]. Adherent cultured cells are detached from the culture dish by trypsinization and collected into a 15 mL tube. After centrifugation, cell pellets are lysed with methanol solution (steps 1–17). The crude lysate and cell debris mixture are treated for highly polar and charged metabolite analysis by CE-TOFMS (steps 18–60). The rest of the mix (200 μL in volume) is solubilized in chloroform to analyze hydrophobic metabolites by LC-QTOFMS (steps 61–89).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. CE-TOFMS and LC-QTOFMS analysis overview
Metabolite extraction from adherent cultured cells
Timing: 1 h
This section describes how to collect cells. For example, we describe the procedure for breast cancer cell line MCF-7.
Culture cells until 80% confluent in a 10 cm dish.
Discard culture medium by aspiration.
Rinse the cells with pre-warmed PBS (-) once.
Add 1 mL of 0.05% trypsin-EDTA solution per 10 cm dish.
Incubate the dish at 37°C for approximately 5 min until the cells are detached from the culture dish.
Add 5 mL of PBS (-) supplemented with 10% FBS.
Transfer the cell suspension into a 15 mL tube (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. An overview of metabolite extraction
(A–H) Extraction steps.
(I) Representative image of cell pellet at step 13. Cells should be firmly pelleted (left). Image of incomplete pellet after subsequent centrifugation (right).
Suspend cells by pipetting.
Count the living cell number using an automated cell counter with trypan blue staining.
Calculate the total cell number in 6 mL of cell suspension.
Centrifuge at 190 × g for 3 min (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Discard the supernatant by aspiration (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Gently pour 5 mL of ice-cold 5% mannitol solution into the tube (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Centrifuge at 190 × g for 3 min (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]E).

Discard the supernatant by aspiration (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F).
Add 1 mL of ice-cold extraction methanol solution with internal reference metabolites (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]G).
Suspend cells by vortexing and store the sample tubes at −80°C until use (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]H).
Note: The concentrations of metabolites are normalized to cell number at step 60. Thus, cell numbers should be counted for all samples at step 9.
Note: In step 5, cells are examined using a phase-contrast microscope to confirm that all cells are entirely detached from the culture dish.
Note: If cells could not be collected well, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 1.
Critical: PBS should be eliminated from samples at step 12 because PBS affects the signal/noise ratio in mass spectrometry analysis.
Also, at step 13, mannitol solution should be added gently to keep cells in pellet form (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]I).
Preparation of charged metabolites for CE-TOFMS analysis
Timing: 5 h
The cell suspension at step 17 contains proteins that increase CE-TOFMS noise. Therefore, additional preparation steps are needed, as previously described (Hirayama et al., 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]).
Transfer 400 μL of cell suspension (from step 17) into a 1.5 mL tube (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. An overview of metabolite preparation
(A-J) Scheme of metabolite preparation.
Add 160 μL of Milli-Q water and 400 μL of chloroform into the tube and mix by vortexing (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Centrifuge at 9,100 × g for 3 min at 4°C (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Confirm that the phase is wholly separated (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
Transfer 400 μL of the supernatant from the methanol/water phase into the filter cassette (Millipore 5-kDa cutoff filter) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E).
Centrifuge at 9,100 × g for 2 h at 20°C (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]F).
Discard the filter cassette and dry the flow-through by centrifugal evaporation at 40°C for 2–3 h (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]G).

Dissolve the dried pellet in 25 μL of the external reference solution and mix by vortexing (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]H).
Transfer 7 μL of the sample into a CE vial (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]I).
Store the vial at −80°C until measurement (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]J).
Prepared metabolite analysis using CE-TOFMS analysis
Highly polar and charged metabolites are analyzed by using a CE-TOFMS system. CE-TOFMS is represented in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A. CE separates metabolites depending on the charge and molecular size. Then, TOFMS detects metabolites by monitoring the range of m/z values.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Parameters for cationic metabolite analysis in CE-TOFMS analysis
(A) Cartoon representation of CE-TOFMS systems used in this protocol.
(B) Cartoon representation of line connections for sheath solution.
(C–E) Screenshots of ChemStation program.
(F) Water bath temperature.
(G–J) Screenshots of MassHunter program.
The CE-TOFMS measurement procedure is composed of two steps, cationic and anionic metabolite analyses (Soga et al., 2003[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9], 2006[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7], 2009[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]). Cationic metabolites analysis measures positively charged metabolites such as amino acids, whereas anionic metabolites analysis detects negatively charged metabolites that are the metabolic intermediates in glycolysis, the pentose phosphate cycle, the TCA cycle, etc.
Next, the application profiles to run CE-TOFMS are shown. We have attached the settings file as supplementary file (Data S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc1.zip] and S2[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc2.zip] for cationic metabolite analysis and Data S3[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc3.zip] and S4[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc4.zip] for anionic metabolite analysis). Users can refer to all the parameters in the file. We review the key parameters that need to be confirmed below.
Critical: To open the setting files Data S1[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc1.zip], S2[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc2.zip], S3[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc3.zip], and S4[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc4.zip], you need to install application software on your PC.
Cationic metabolite analysis
Timing: 2 days
Run ChemStation and MassHunter Workstation Data Acquisition B.02.01 on a PC.
Note: ChemStation is run to control the isocratic pump and CE, whereas MassHunter controls TOFMS.
Preparation of fused silica capillary (Polymicro Technologies).

Cut the fused silica capillary to approximately 100 cm in length.
Peel polyimide-coating at one end of the capillary. The coating should be removed 3–4 mm from the end of the capillary.
Wipe off the peeled capillary with 50% 2-propanol/Milli-Q water.
Connect the capillary to the sprayer of TOFMS at the coating-free side, and the other side of the capillary to the CE cassette.
Run the Flush program with 1 M formic acid for 20 min.
Prepare 80 mL of sheath solution (50% methanol containing 0.1 μM hexakis (2,2-difluoroethoxy) phosphazene) in a 100 mL bottle.
Connect the line of sheath solution to the isocratic pump.
Run the Purge program with the sheath solution at 5 mL/min flow rate for 3 min.
Note: The line connection between a sheath bottle and an isocratic pump is summarized in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B.
Change the flow rate of the sheath solution to 1 mL/min on ChemStation (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).
Note: One flow line goes into the MS equipment at a flow rate of 10 μL/min, and the other line goes to an original sheath bottle (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Set up the CE method for cationic metabolites analysis in the ChemStation program.
Inject the sample solution (from procedure step 26) at 50 mbar for 5 s (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D).
Fill the capillary with 1 M formic acid as an electrolyte at 50 mbar for 4 s (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D).
Keep the capillary temperature (Cassette Temperature) at 20°C.
Set the parameters of the High Voltage System at 30 kV (Voltage), 50 μA (Current), and 5 W (Power) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E).
After running one sample, push out the capillary inside with 1 M formic acid washing buffer for 4 min to prevent contamination between samples (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E).
Set the water bath temperature for cooling the sample tray at 4°C (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]F).

Run the following sample.
Set up the TOFMS method for cationic metabolites analysis in the MassHunter program.
Check “Positive” at Ion Polarity (Seg) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]G).
Set the Dual ESI (Seg) parameters at Gas Temp: 300°C, Drying Gas: 10 L/min, and Nebulizer: 7 psig (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]H).
Set the capillary voltage at 4,000 V (Dual ESI (Expt), VCap) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]H).
Set the voltage parameters for the TOFMS setting (MS TOF (Expt)), the fragmentor, Skimmer, and OCT1 RFVpp voltages at 75 V, 50 V, and 500 V, respectively (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]H).
Set the Acquisition range (Mass Range) at Min Range m/z 50 and Max Range m/z 1000 (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]I).
Set the Acquisition Rate/Time at 1.5 spectra/s (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]I).
Perform Automatic recalibration of each acquired spectrum using reference masses of reference standards included in the sheath solution.
Set Auto Recalibration Parameters as in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]J.
Note: The 13C isotopic ion of a protonated methanol dimer ([2MeOH+H]+, m/z 66.063061) and Hexakis (2,2-difluoroethoxy) phosphazene ([M+H]+, m/z 622.028963) are referenced as a lock mass for exact mass measurement (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]J).
Create a worklist file in the MassHunter program for running CE-TOFMS.
Run standard mixture first to check the total ion chromatogram (TIC).
Critical: If the TIC spectrum is not stable, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 2.
Run the worklist program.
Check the graph of the current.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1814_15.csv
Note: The current should be kept around 35 μA for cationic metabolite analysis. If the current value shows inconsistency, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 3 or Problem 4.
Note: Program to replace both the 1 M formic acid washing buffer and the 1 M formic acid electrolyte every ten samples. This program analyzes samples and a standard mixture from 272 compounds listed in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]. The reference compounds are used for the quantification of target metabolites.
Anionic metabolite analysis
Timing: 2 days

Run ChemStation and MassHunter Workstation Data Acquisition B.02.01 on a PC.
Note: ChemStation is run to control the isocratic pump and CE, whereas MassHunter controls TOFMS.
Prepare COSMO (+) capillary, which is chemically coated with a cationic polymer.
Replace the storage solution with 50 mM ammonium acetate solution (pH 8.5) using a 1 mL syringe.
Critical: COSMO (+) capillary has a storage solution inside. The storage solution must be replaced with 50 mM ammonium acetate solution.
Cut the capillary approximately 105 cm in length.
Peel polyimide coating at one end of the capillary.
Note: The coating should be removed 3–4 mm from the end of the capillary.
Wipe off the tip of the capillary with 50% 2-propanol/Milli-Q.
Connect the capillary to the sprayer of TOFMS at the coating-free side, and the other side of the capillary should be connected to the CE cassette.
Run Flush program with 50 mM ammonium acetate solution (pH 8.5) for 10 min.
Run Flush program with 50 mM ammonium acetate solution (pH 3.4) for 10 min.
Run Flush program with 50 mM ammonium acetate solution (pH 8.5) for 10 min.
Prepare 80 mL of sheath solution (5 mM ammonium acetate in 50% methanol containing 0.1 μM Hexakis (2,2-difluoroethoxy) phosphazene) in a 100 mL bottle.
Connect the line from sheath solution bottle to the isocratic pump.
Run the Purge program with the sheath solution at 5 mL/min flow rate for 3 min.
Note: The line connection between a sheath solution bottle and an isocratic pump is summarized in Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B.
Change the flow rate to 1 mL/min for measurement in ChemStation program (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Parameters of CE-TOFMS method for cationic metabolite analysis
(A–C) Screenshots of ChemStation program.
(D) Water bath temperature.
(E–H) Screenshots of MassHunter program.

Set up CE method for anionic metabolites analysis in ChemStation program.
Keep the capillary temperature (Cassette Temperature) at 20°C (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Inject the sample solution at 50 mbar for 30 s (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Fill the capillary with 50 mM ammonium acetate solution (pH 8.5) at 50 mbar for 4 s (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
Set the parameters of the High Voltage System at -30 kV (Voltage), 50 μA (Current), and 5 W (Power) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B).
After running one sample, wash the capillary with 50 mM ammonium acetate solution (pH 3.4) for 2 min (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C).
Wash the capillary with 50 mM ammonium acetate solution (pH 8.5) for 5 min (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]C).
Set the temperature of the water bath for cooling the sample tray at 4°C (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]D).
Run a subsequent sample.
Set up the TOFMS method for anionic metabolite analysis in the MassHunt program.
Check “Negative” at the section of Ion Polarity (Seg) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]E).
Set the Dual ESI (Seg) parameters at Gas Temp: 300°C, Drying Gas: 10 L/min, and Nebulizer: 7 psig (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]F).
Set the capillary voltage (Dual ESI (Expt)) at 3,500 V (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]F).
Set the fragmentor, skimmer, and OCT1 RFVpp voltages at 100 V, 50 V, and 500 V, respectively in the TOFMS setting (MS TOF (Expt)) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]F).
Set the Acquisition range (Mass Range) from Min Range m/z 50 to Max Range m/z 1,000 with an Acquisition Rate/Time of 1.51 spectra/s (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]G).
Perform Automatic recalibration of each acquired spectrum by using reference masses of reference standards.
Set Auto Recalibration Parameters as in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]H.
Note: The 13C isotopic ion of deprotonated acetic acid dimer ([2CH3COOH-H]−, m/z 120.038339) and Hexakis (2,2-difluoroethoxy) phosphazene + deprotonated acetic acid (m/z 680.035541) are referenced as the lock mass for exact mass measurement (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]H).

Create a worklist file in the MassHunter program for running CE-TOF/MS.
Run standard mixture first to check total ion chromatogram (TIC).
Critical: If the TIC spectrum is not stable, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 2.
Run the worklist program.
Check the graph of the current.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1814_16.csv
Critical: The current should be kept at around 30 μA for analysis of anionic metabolites. If the current value shows inconsistency, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 3 or Problem 4.
Note: Fifty mM ammonium acetate (both pH 3.4 and pH 8.5) washing buffer and 50 mM ammonium acetate (pH 8.5) electrolyte should be replaced every ten runs. Samples and 237 standard compounds listed in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] can be analyzed. The reference metabolites will be measured for quantification and validation of target metabolites.
Data analysis of CE-TOFMS
Timing: 2 days
Raw data are processed by using MasterHands (Sugimoto et al., 2010[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib12]). Each peak of metabolites is identified by matching m/z values and the normalized migration times of reference compounds.
Data processing comprises data conversion and peak integration from every raw data. The processed data are aligned, and a data matrix is yielded after filling missing peaks (Sugimoto et al., 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]).
MassHunter makes the files of each sample in the “.d zip” folder.
Convert each data .d folder to a .kiff zip by using a data conversion mode of MasterHands (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Screenshots of the MasterHands program for data processing
(A–D) The screenshot images of the MasterHands program.
Load all data .kiff files on the MasterHands program (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Detect every peak with default options. Parameters for peak detection are S/N cutoff: 2 and valley (%): 50 (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C).
Determine the internal reference component peak and external reference component peak in all samples, as shown in Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]D.

Note: Internal reference components are methionine sulfone for cation and D-Camphor-10-sulfonic acid for the anion. External reference components are 3-Aminopyrrolidine for cationic metabolites and trimesate for anionic metabolites. Internal and external references are used to correct the migration time of metabolites in samples. Also, the area values of the internal references are used for the standardization of metabolites.
Run the alignment function to correct the migration time of the targeted metabolite among the samples.
Identify the signal peak by comparing with the peak of a mixed reference.
Note: If the signal peak is not clear, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 5.
Note: On isobaric metabolites, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 6.
Export a csv file for the calculation of concentration.
Calculate the normalized concentration of each metabolite in the sample by using the following formulas.

Sample Area; Peak area of the targeting metabolite in a sample. Sample ISArea; Peak area of methionine sulfone or D-Camphor-10-sulfonic acid in a sample. Standard Area; Peak area of the targeting metabolite in 1× standard metabolite mixture for anionic or cationic metabolite analysis. Standard ISArea; Peak area of methionine sulfone or D-Camphor-10-sulfonic acid in 1× standard metabolite mixture for anionic or cationic metabolite analysis. 20 μM; standard concentration in 1× standard metabolite mixture for cationic or anionic metabolite analysis. 25 μM; the concentration of methionine sulfone or D-Camphor-10-sulfonic acid in extraction methanol with reference metabolites. 200 μM; the concentration of methionine sulfone or D-Camphor-10-sulfonic acid in 1× standard metabolite mixture for anionic or cationic metabolite analysis.

Solubilization of hydrophobic metabolites for LC-QTOFMS analysis
Timing: 1 h
Whole lipid metabolites are extracted from biological materials (Bligh and Dyer, 1959[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16]). Briefly, hydrophobic metabolites are dissolved in chloroform and are analyzed by LC-QTOFMS system with a high-sensitivity full-scan mode. A pooled sample from each analyte is analyzed by LC-QTOFMS system with product ion scan mode (Calderón-Santiago et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]; Spickett and Pitt, 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]).
Transfer a 200 μL volume of cell sample (from step 17) into a 2 mL glass jacket tube and add 20 μL of Milli-Q water (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. An overview of solubilization of hydrophobic metabolites for LC-QTOFMS analysis
(A–F) The schematic representation of pareparation steps for hydrophobic metabloites.
Add 100 μL of chloroform using a glass tip and mix by vortexing (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B).
Centrifuge at 2,400 × g for 20 min at 20°C using a swinging rotor centrifuge (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]C).
Transfer 200 μL of the supernatant into a glass insert assembled in a glass vial (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]D) and store samples at −80°C until measurement (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]E).
Note: If the sample forms two layers, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 7.
For product ion scan analysis, make a pooled sample by mixing 10–20 μL of each sample for measurement (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]F).
Store samples at −80°C until measurement (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]E).
Critical: Glassware should be used for tips and tubes in the presence of chloroform to avoid plastic contamination.
Hydrophobic metabolite analysis by LC-QTOFMS
Timing: 2 days
The LC-QTOFMS system is represented as a cartoon in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A. Briefly, hydrophobic metabolites are separated on a reversed-phase LC column, and QTOFMS determines the molecular masses of major eluted species.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Parameters of the MassHunter program for LC analysis by full scan mode
(A) Cartoon representation of LC-QTOFMS systems used in this protocol.
(B–F) Screenshots of MassHunter program.

We have attached the setting file as supplementary file (Data S5[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc5.zip], S6[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc6.zip], S7[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc7.zip], S8[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc8.zip], S9[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc9.zip], S10[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc10.zip], S11[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc11.zip], and S12[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc12.zip]). Users can refer to all the parameters in the file. We review the key parameters that should be confirmed in the following section.
Critical: To open the setting files Data S5[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc5.zip], S6[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc6.zip], S7[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc7.zip], S8[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc8.zip], S9[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc9.zip], S10[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc10.zip], S11[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc11.zip], and S12[href=https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Mmc12.zip], you need to install application software on your PC.
Run MassHunter Data Acquisition B.08.00 Software on PC.
Note: All machine settings should be modified through this application program.
Prepare 1 L of mobile phase A solution (5 mM ammonium formate in acetonitrile-methanol-water (3:1:1)) and 1 L of mobile phase B solution (5 mM ammonium formate in 2-propanol) in a 1 L bottle.
Connect the mobile phase A solution line to the binary pump at channel A and the mobile phase B at channel B.
Run the Purge program at 5 mL/min flow rate for 3 min.
Prepare 100 mL of 2-propanol for needle wash solution in a 300 mL bottle and connect the needle wash line to the autosampler.
Prepare 80 mL of 1× reference solution in a 100 mL bottle and set it in the isocratic pump.
Run the Purge program with reference solution at a 5 mL/min flow rate for 3 min.
Change the flow rate of the reference solution to 1 mL/min (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B).
Set the column (Acquity UPLC HSS T3 C18 column 2.1 mm i.d. × 50 mm, 1.8 μm; Waters, Milford, MA) in LC system.
Set up the LC method.
Set flow rate at 0.3 mL/min (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]C).
Prepare the gradient profiles of solvent B as described in Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]C (right panel).

Note: The ratios of solvent B are 0% at 0 min, 40% at 5 min, 64% at 7.5 min, 64% at 12 min, 82.5% at 12.5, 85% at 19 min, and 95% at 20 min. Post time is set at 4 min (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]C).
Set the Injection volume of samples at 5 μL (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]D).
Set the column temperature (Temperature Left) at 45°C.
Check “Combined” at Temperature Right (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]E).
Set the autosampler temperature (Thermostat Temperature Control) at 4°C (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]F).
Set up QTOFMS method for full scan analysis.
Note: Full scan analysis should be run by positive and negative modes. Thus, the QTOFMS setting should be prepared for positive and negative modes (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A). Meanwhile, product ion scan analysis should be run on only negative mode, but the method file should be prepared for each lipid class (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A). Here we show the case for the positive mode.
Select positive at Ion Polarity (Seg) (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]B).
In Dual ESI (Seg) window, set the following parameters; Gas Temp: 350°C, Drying Gas: 10 L/min, and Nebulizer: 55 psig (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]C).
Set the capillary voltage (Dual ESI (Expt), VCap) at 3,500 V (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]C).
In MS TOF (Expt) section, set the Fragmentor, Skimmer, and Oct1 RFVpp voltages at 150 V, 90 V, and 500 V, respectively (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]C).
In the Spectral Parameters part, set the Acquisition range (Mass Range) at Min Range m/z 100 and Max Range m/z 1,700.
Set the Acquisition Rate/Time at 1.5 spectra/s (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]D).
Perform Automatic recalibration by using two reference masses of reference standards, as shown in Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]E.
Note: Positive mode: [purine + H]+, m/z 121.050873 and [hexakis (1H,1H,3H-tetrafluoropropoxy) phosphazene + H]+, m/z 922.009798. Negative mode: [trifluoroacetic acid - H]-, m/z 112.985587 and [hexakis (1H,1H,3H-tetrafluoropropoxy +trifluoroacetic acid - H]-, m/z 1033.988109

Create a similar method file with negative mode.
Set up QTOFMS method for product ion scan analysis.
Select negative mode in the Ion Polarity (Seg) part (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]A).
Input the Dual ESI (Seg) values as Gas Temp: 350°C, Drying Gas: 10 L/min, and Nebulizer: 55 psig (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]B).
Set the capillary voltage (Dual ESI (Expt)) at 3,500 V (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]B).
Input MS TOF (Expt) values as Fragmentor: 150 V; Skimmer: 90 V; and Oct1 RFVpp: 500 (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]B).
In the Acquisition tab, check “Auto MS/MS (Seg) mode” and input Mass Range values as Min Range m/z 100 and Max Range m/z 1,100 in both MS and MS/MS sections (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C).
Set the Acquisition Rate/Time at 1.5 spectra/s for MS and at 2 spectra/s for MS/MS (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C).
Select “Narrow (m/z 1.3)” in Isolation Width for MS/MS (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]C).
In the Precursor Selection I tab, set 3 Max Precursors Per Cycle (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]D).
In the Precursor Threshold part, set Abs. Threshold as 10,000 counts (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]D).
Change the collision energy value in the Collision Energy tab depending on the phospholipid class.
Check “Use Fixed Collision Energies” and enter the value of the Collision Energy column listed in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3].
Note: We show the example of phosphatidic acid in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]E. The collision energy should be optimized depending on the instruments used as shown in the following section “optimization of collision energy for product ion scan[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec4.9]”.
Note: The precursor m/z of each phospholipid in Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]F is summarized in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3].
Perform Automatic recalibration by using two reference masses of reference standards (shown below, Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]G).
Note: Negative mode: [trifluoroacetic acid - H]-, m/z 112.985587 and [hexakis (1H,1H,3H-tetrafluoropropoxy +trifluoroacetic acid - H]-, m/z 1033.988109

Create method files for each class of phospholipids so that the Product ion scan can be executed for each category.
Note: In total, six methods should be created (for phosphatidylserine, phosphatidic acid, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylglycerol, and phosphatidylinositol).
Create a worklist in the MassHunter program.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. The parameters for the QTOFMS method for product ion scan analysis
(A) Schematic representation of the method’s files prepared in this protocol.
(B–E) Screenshots of the MassHunter program.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. The parameters for the QTOFMS method
(A–G) Screenshot of the MassHunter program.
table:files/protocols_protocol_1814_17.csv
(A:B) A; The number of carbon in fatty acids, B; The number of double bond in fatty acids.
Run the worklist program.
Note: Samples are analyzed in independent runs in positive and negative modes using the conditions for full scan analysis. The pooled sample is analyzed six times in negative mode using product ion scan analysis.
Note: Check the column pressure during measurement. If the column pressure increases more than 50 mbar from the start, refer to troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] Problem 8.
Optimization of collision energy for product ion scan
Timing: 1 day
The collision energy should be optimized depending on the instruments. Next, we describe the step of collision energy optimization for product ion scan. The optimization of collision energy is performed in each phospholipid class using five phospholipid standards. The standards are listed in Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4].
table:files/protocols_protocol_1814_18.csv
Dissolve the set-up standards in methanol at 10 μM final concentration.
Transfer each standard solution into LC vials.
Run LC-QTOFMS with the collision energy in the range between 10 eV and 50 eV.
Check the intensity of the evaluation spectrums listed in Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4].
Select the collision energy that shows high intensity in all evaluation spectrums.
Data analysis for LC-QTOFMS in full scan
Timing: 2 days

Data analysis of LC-QTOFMS data is the same way as analyzing the data of CE-TOFMS except for the calculation of metabolite concentration (Refer to steps 52–59). The retention times of LC-QTOFMS is shown as the two-dimensional map (Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1814-Fig11.jpg
Figure 11. Example of LC-QTOFMS data
(A) The retention time of lipid classes.
(B) Mass spectrum data.
The amount of hydrophobic metabolite is normalized with cell number.
Data analysis for LC-QTOFMS in product ion scan to identify the phospholipid class
Timing: 1 day
Product ion scan analysis data are imported into the MassHuter Qualitative Analysis software to identify the class of fatty acids with respect to phospholipid. The phospholipid is evaluated by m/z value and the presence of fatty acid-derived peaks. The MassBank data identifies the phospholipid class (Horai et al., 2010[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]; Taguchi et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13]; Taguchi and Ishikawa, 2010[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14]).
Note: For the analysis of pooled samples, a data folder “.d zip” is yielded by MassHunter. The data folder is processed by MassHunter Qualitative Analysis software.
Display Fragment mass spectra (Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]B).
Check the peak of neutral loss and polar head-derived spectrum.
Note: The spectrum m/z is summarized in Table 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl5].
Check the peak of the fatty acid spectrum.
Note: The spectrum m/z is summarized in Table 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl6].
Identify the phospholipid metabolites based on the characters from steps 87 and 88.
